Benjamin Ehrenberg.title: Quantifying Value-Adds Methodology
Benjamin Ehrenberg.description: Repeatable framework for tracking gratuitous services with dollar figures (frequent setups, escort avoidance, out-of-scope work)
Benjamin Ehrenberg.context: At Lockheed Martin, Ben needed to demonstrate value beyond base contract scope. The challenge: clients see routine service execution as 'just doing your job,' not as added value. Ben created a systematic framework to track and quantify all gratuitous services with actual dollar figures - things like frequent last-minute setups, escort avoidance, and out-of-scope work that other vendors would charge for. This transforms client perception from 'meeting expectations' to 'delivering measurable partnership value.' Leadership explicitly challenged Ben to implement this in 2026 as it provides powerful retention ammunition during renewals by showing documented cost avoidance.
Benjamin Ehrenberg.impact: Demonstrates true partnership value; provides retention ammunition during renewals

Mark Schlerf.title: Gap Analysis as Strategic Opportunity Framework
Mark Schlerf.description: Turn CBRE Lam Research gap analysis (potential minefield showing contract vs. actual performance) into strategic investment opportunities by showing 'what is different by location and what the opportunities are' for client to fund improvements
Mark Schlerf.context: When CBRE asked Mark to conduct a gap analysis at Lam Research comparing contract language to actual performance across sites, it could have been a landmine - exposing service deficiencies and creating ammunition for price reduction or termination. Instead, Mark strategically reframed it as an opportunity identification exercise. He showed 'what is different by location' and presented the gaps as investment opportunities for the client to fund scope improvements. This turned a potential liability into a value conversation, positioning SBM as a strategic partner rather than a vendor under scrutiny. Nick Viskovich praised this approach as a masterclass in strategic thinking.
Mark Schlerf.impact: Converted potential liability into client investment in scope improvements

Mark Schlerf.title: JLL Quarterly Operations Reviews Cadence
Mark Schlerf.description: Structured quarterly review process with IFM partners to align on performance, innovation, and growth
Mark Schlerf.context: Mark established a disciplined quarterly review cadence with JLL as the IFM partner across his portfolio. These aren't reactive check-ins but proactive strategic sessions covering performance metrics, innovation roadmaps, and growth opportunities. This governance model has strengthened the IFM relationship to the point where renewals happen off-market without competitive bidding. Nick Viskovich noted this as a replicable best practice that creates predictability and reduces client anxiety while positioning SBM as an indispensable strategic partner rather than a transactional vendor.
Mark Schlerf.impact: Strengthened IFM relationships; secured off-market renewals
Mark Schlerf.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich noted as strong governance model

Grant Frazier.title: Luna's Standard Cadence for Transitions
Grant Frazier.description: Standardized weekly client update process for transitions; drove all standard processes forward systematically
Grant Frazier.context: When Meta awarded SBM two massive new campuses (Fremont and Sunnyvale totaling $800K in new revenue), Grant's operations manager Luna created a systematic weekly client update framework specifically for transitions. The process included standardized checkpoints: staffing status, quality metrics, client feedback loops, issue resolution, and next week's priorities. This disciplined cadence stabilized Fremont in just 1.5 months and Sunnyvale in 3 months - remarkably fast for sites of this scale. Grant openly credited Luna: 'I wouldn't have done that without Luna's ability to make those standards.' Leadership praised this as a replicable playbook for all future transitions to reduce client anxiety and accelerate revenue stabilization.
Grant Frazier.impact: Stabilized Fremont in 1.5 months, Sunnyvale in 3 months; Grant: 'I wouldn't have done that without Luna's ability to make those standards'
Grant Frazier.leadership_endorsement: Grant explicitly credited Luna; Val/Nick praised execution

Grant Frazier.title: Sub-Tenant Day Porter Revenue Model
Grant Frazier.description: Strategic placement of day porters for sub-tenants in property management buildings; positions SBM as exclusive provider
Grant Frazier.context: In property management buildings (like Meta's San Francisco HQ at SF181), Grant identified untapped revenue: sub-tenants (Klavio, Mercor) wanted dedicated day porter services but had no direct facilities relationship. Traditional vendors only serve the building owner. Grant positioned SBM as the exclusive provider to ALL building occupants, adding 3.5 FTE day porters serving multiple sub-tenants for $34K in incremental revenue. This micro-innovation model is portable to any multi-tenant building nationally and demonstrates SBM's strategic thinking beyond traditional janitorial scope. Nick Viskovich praised this as differentiated business development thinking.
Grant Frazier.impact: $34k revenue from 3.5 FTE; client sees consolidation value

Stuart Kelloff.title: 12-Month Renewal Planning Strategy
Stuart Kelloff.description: Plan NVIDIA renewal throughout all of 2025 for April 2026 expiration (not just last 3-4 months); consistent implementation of reinvestment practices throughout the year
Stuart Kelloff.context: Most Account Directors plan renewals 3-4 months before expiration, leading to last-minute scrambles and client skepticism. Stuart took a radically different approach for NVIDIA's April 2026 renewal: he planned throughout ALL of 2025, implementing consistent reinvestment practices as an operating rhythm rather than a 'renewal push.' This means tiered wage increases, equipment upgrades, and governance improvements happened steadily all year. The result: NVIDIA positioned to renew early in February (2 months ahead), avoided RFP risk, and is now going on year 9 with SBM (3rd consecutive renewal). Leadership gave this approach 5/5 scores and cited it as a best practice for de-risking renewals and building genuine partnerships.
Stuart Kelloff.impact: Positioned for early renewal in February; mitigated RFP; going on year 9 with SBM (3rd consecutive renewal)
Stuart Kelloff.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett praised; Nick Viskovich gave 5/5

Stuart Kelloff.title: Tiered Wage Rate Structure / Frontline Reinvestment
Stuart Kelloff.description: Ground-up wage structure from starting to experienced employees; reinvest margin into team vs client cost reduction
Stuart Kelloff.context: For NVIDIA's renewal, Stuart worked with the client to create a tiered wage rate structure built from the ground up - differentiating starting employees from experienced staff. Instead of taking margin to the bottom line or reducing client costs, Stuart reinvested the savings back into the frontline team through wage increases and career progression pathways. NVIDIA saw this as partnership behavior rather than profit extraction. The client explicitly wanted this reinvestment approach as part of the renewal strategy. Nick Viskovich gave this 5/5 for value-add, noting it improves retention, reduces training costs, and positions SBM as an employer of choice.
Stuart Kelloff.impact: Retention improved; client sees partnership value; positioned for renewal success

Stuart Kelloff.title: Weekly Scorecard Reviews with Client
Stuart Kelloff.description: Structured weekly review cadence with NVIDIA/CBRE on performance metrics, safety, quality
Stuart Kelloff.context: Stuart established a structured weekly (not monthly, not quarterly) scorecard review with NVIDIA and CBRE covering performance metrics, safety incidents, quality scores, and upcoming initiatives. This creates a predictable rhythm where issues surface early and get resolved before they escalate. It also demonstrates transparency and partnership commitment that monthly reviews can't match. Leadership noted this as a governance best practice that reduces client complaints by 60%+, strengthens partnership perception, and serves as an early warning system. The discipline of weekly reviews forces operational excellence and eliminates the 'hoping problems go away' trap.
Stuart Kelloff.impact: Proactive issue identification; strengthened trust; reduced surprises
Stuart Kelloff.leadership_endorsement: Leadership noted as governance best practice

Jacqueline Maravilla.title: Non-Routine to ATB Budget Conversion
Jacqueline Maravilla.description: Identified non-routine work orders consuming SOW headcount; met with customer and got approval to pull non-routine onto above-the-base
Jacqueline Maravilla.context: At Alonza, Jacqueline's budget was persistently red despite hitting service levels. Deep analysis revealed non-routine work orders (urgent cleanings, emergency responses, GMP area shutdowns) were consuming SOW headcount budget but weren't being billed separately - classic scope creep. She met directly with the Alonza customer and proposed moving all non-routine work to above-the-base billing. The client agreed, generating $6K/month in sustained additional revenue while freeing up SOW headcount for actual routine work. This systematic approach to scope management turned the account from red to green and protected margins without sacrificing service quality. Nick Viskovich and Dan Hartman praised this as a replicable methodology for identifying hidden revenue.
Jacqueline Maravilla.impact: $6k/month sustained additional revenue; freed up SOW headcount for routine work; resolved budget red status
Jacqueline Maravilla.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich praised; Dan Hartman noted financial impact

Paul Rhodes.title: Holistic Account Strategy (Unifying Silos)
Paul Rhodes.description: Unite siloed regional operations (Bay Area vs Americas) into one holistic view; initiatives flow between regions; Seattle POCs had 'no idea' about Bay Area innovations
Paul Rhodes.context: Google's operations are siloed by region - Bay Area and Americas operate independently with separate QBRs and strategies. Paul discovered Seattle POCs had 'no idea' about innovations happening in the Bay Area, and vice versa. JLL doesn't communicate internally across regions, so Paul is intentionally positioning himself as the connector, creating one unified Google view. This means initiatives can flow between regions, decision-making becomes more informed, and there are fewer surprises. Paul's goal for 2026-2027 is to unite these silos completely, creating enterprise visibility and alignment that JLL can't provide. Leadership acknowledged this strategic gap and praised Paul for identifying the opportunity.
Paul Rhodes.impact: Clearer visibility and alignment; smarter decision-making; fewer surprises; Paul acts as communicator between regions (JLL doesn't communicate internally)
Paul Rhodes.leadership_endorsement: Paul explicitly called out as intentional strategy; leadership acknowledged gap

Kimberly Wittekind.title: Leadership Addition Without Client Cost
Kimberly Wittekind.description: Added Andrew Daria as project administrator (functions as account manager) by reallocating budget; no additional cost to client
Kimberly Wittekind.context: GE Healthcare was growing rapidly and Kimberly couldn't be in multiple places at once, but the unique scope (cleaning medical equipment, not buildings) requires specialized training and sign-offs. Rather than asking GE for budget approval (which could take months), she reallocated existing budget to add Andrew Daria as a project administrator who functions as an account manager. Andrew built trust with client POC Kellyanne, supported the difficult New Orleans transition, and provides $120K/year in value to GE at zero additional cost. This creative constraint management impressed Nick Viskovich and Val as a model for scaling leadership without client pushback.
Kimberly Wittekind.impact: $120k/year value-add to GE; huge asset for customer relationships and New Orleans transition support
Kimberly Wittekind.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich praised; Val noted creative constraint management

Ana Sabater.title: Tiered Cost Initiatives (Platinum/Gold/Silver)
Ana Sabater.description: Delivered detailed cost optimization proposal to CBRE with tiered service models (Platinum, Gold, Silver) showing savings options
Ana Sabater.context: At LinkedIn HQ, Ana delivered a detailed cost optimization proposal with tiered service levels (Platinum, Gold, Silver) showing exactly what CBRE could achieve at different price points and service frequencies. Currently at Platinum, the client can see what Gold or Silver would look like and make informed trade-offs. This pricing flexibility model is highly portable - it shows partnership thinking rather than 'take it or leave it' pricing, positions SBM as a strategic advisor, and gives the client control over their budget. Nick and Val praised this as strategic thinking that strengthens renewal positioning and differentiates SBM from vendors who only present one price point.
Ana Sabater.impact: Portable pricing flexibility model; client sees partnership value; positions for renewal

Isaac Calderon.title: J&J Error Tracker (Log Book Quality Tool)
Isaac Calderon.description: Quality team implemented tracker for log book compliance; targeted corrective actions for misses
Isaac Calderon.context: At Johnson & Johnson, log book compliance was a persistent client challenge - missed entries became audit targets. Isaac's quality team implemented a systematic error tracker specifically for log book compliance, enabling targeted corrective actions for any misses. Result: log books are no longer a challenge or target for J&J audits, and the quality improvement has been sustained over time. Marvin Owens praised this innovation as a simple but effective quality management tool that's highly replicable across any account with documentation compliance requirements. The key: don't just fix errors, track patterns and prevent recurrence.
Isaac Calderon.impact: Log books no longer a challenge/target for J&J; quality improvement sustained

Isaac Calderon.title: Cambion Transition Playbook (6-Step Framework)
Isaac Calderon.description: 6-step transition framework: 1) Leadership alignment, 2) Staff retention strategy, 3) Training SOP documentation, 4) Client communication cadence, 5) Quick wins identification, 6) 90-day performance baseline
Isaac Calderon.context: Isaac developed a documented 6-step transition framework for the Cambion account: 1) Leadership alignment (get everyone on same page), 2) Staff retention strategy (identify and keep key talent), 3) Training SOP documentation (don't rely on tribal knowledge), 4) Client communication cadence (weekly updates, not ad hoc), 5) Quick wins identification (show value fast), 6) 90-day performance baseline (measure progress). This systematic playbook delivered a smooth transition with strong client confidence and retained key staff. Marvin Owens noted the strong execution. The framework is highly replicable - it eliminates transition guesswork and ensures consistent handoff quality regardless of who's executing.
Isaac Calderon.impact: Smooth transition; strong client confidence; retained key staff

Patrick Murtha.title: Subcontractor Portfolio Optimization
Patrick Murtha.description: Systematic review of Cardinal Health subcontracted sites driving $5k/month red; pricing exercises with multiple contractors; negotiated 5% savings with current providers; switched Tolson AZ provider for 47% savings ($3,400 to $1,810)
Patrick Murtha.context: Patrick's Cardinal Health portfolio was $5K/month red, driven by subcontracted sites where costs exceeded revenue. Rather than accept the loss, he conducted a systematic review: pricing exercises with multiple contractors, negotiations with current providers (achieved 5% savings), and competitive switches where justified (Tolson AZ: 47% savings, dropping from $3,400 to $1,810/month). This systematic approach moved the entire Cardinal portfolio from red to green. Zach Shock praised the methodology as highly replicable for any AD managing subcontracted sites. The key: don't accept subcontractor pricing as fixed - continuously optimize like you would with direct labor.
Patrick Murtha.impact: Cardinal portfolio moved from red to green; systematic approach to margin recovery

Patrick Murtha.title: IQVIA Marietta Operational Reset Framework
Patrick Murtha.description: On-site visit to develop routes for AM/PM shifts; created task checklists; established bi-weekly meetings with CBRE and POC; developed action plan (area mgmt on-site for events, phone calls vs email, increased communication)
Patrick Murtha.context: IQVIA Marietta was failing - low CSAT scores, high turnover, no defined routes, staff didn't know the scope. Patrick went on-site and built the operational foundation from scratch: developed routes for AM/PM shifts, created task checklists, established bi-weekly meetings with CBRE and POC, and created an action plan (area management on-site for major events, phone calls instead of emails for urgent issues, increased communication cadence). POC feedback after reset: 'No issues, things are great.' Strong relationship with new area manager sustained the improvement. Valarie Barnett acknowledged Patrick's transparency; Zach Shock praised execution. Highly replicable turnaround playbook.
Patrick Murtha.impact: POC feedback: 'No issues, things are great'; strong relationship with new area manager
Patrick Murtha.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett acknowledged transparency; Zach Shock praised execution

Patrick Murtha.title: Cardinal Greenwood Crisis-to-Opportunity
Patrick Murtha.description: Failed CSAT recovery: identified misalignment between Cardinal and JLL (new business unit, increased headcount); meeting with JLL corporate/regional; site walk with both POCs; updated scope; wage pass-through ($2/hr, 5th to 26th percentile); $7,034/month revenue increase
Patrick Murtha.context: Cardinal Greenwood failed a CSAT. During recovery, Patrick discovered a misalignment: Cardinal had opened a new business unit and increased headcount, but JLL didn't know about it. There was confusion between JLL and Cardinal about who owned what. Patrick organized a meeting with JLL corporate/regional leadership and both POCs, conducted a site walk, and identified the scope gaps. Solution: updated scope, secured a $2/hr wage pass-through (moving staff from 5th to 26th percentile for the market), and generated $7,034/month in additional revenue. This closed the gap between JLL and Cardinal while positioning SBM as the problem-solver who brings parties together. Zach Shock gave 5/5 for transparency and execution.
Patrick Murtha.impact: Closed gap between JLL and Cardinal; positioned SBM as problem-solver
Patrick Murtha.leadership_endorsement: Zach Shock gave 5/5 for transparency and execution

Aaron Simpson.title: 4insite Live Presentation Model
Aaron Simpson.description: Aaron presented entirely from 4insite dashboards (no PowerPoint); 'How we actually speak to our customers, what they're seeing and looking at'
Aaron Simpson.context: Instead of creating a PowerPoint for his year-end review, Aaron presented entirely from live 4insite dashboards - the same interface his customers see every day. His rationale: 'This is how we actually speak to our customers, what they're seeing and looking at.' This demonstrates ultimate transparency and confidence in the data. Valarie Barnett's reaction: 'I haven't seen anyone perform their review this way... this is exactly the way I would have done it. This is a best practice and an example.' Highly replicable - it changes the conversation from 'Here's what I'm telling you' to 'Here's what the data shows us together.' Builds unshakeable credibility.
Aaron Simpson.impact: Val: 'I haven't seen anyone perform their review this way... this is exactly the way I would have done it. This is a best practice and an example.'
Aaron Simpson.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett explicitly called out as best practice

Aaron Simpson.title: Lean Right-Sized Staffing (3M Model)
Aaron Simpson.description: 1 turnover in 2025, 0 after January; low touch, high reliability; no dependency on leadership; 399 days recordable-free; 4.5 internal score; zero failed audits
Aaron Simpson.context: At 3M Detroit, Aaron achieved the holy grail: 1 turnover in all of 2025 (0 after January), 399 days recordable-free, 4.5 internal audit score, zero failed audits, and the site runs with minimal leadership intervention - 'low touch, high reliability.' This is a lean, right-sized staffing model that's perfectly calibrated to the scope. The site is so stable that Aaron wants to use it as his governance benchmark for other accounts. Nick Viskovich praised this as a model site. The key: right-sizing isn't about cutting costs, it's about finding the exact staffing level that delivers consistent quality with minimal noise. Highly replicable methodology.
Aaron Simpson.impact: Low noise, high margin, high satisfaction; Aaron wants to use 3M as governance benchmark
Aaron Simpson.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich praised as benchmark model

Aaron Simpson.title: Data Transparency Reset / Bi-Weekly RFM Reviews
Aaron Simpson.description: Bi-weekly scorecard reviews with RFMs (not just area managers); Aaron now directly captures RFM feedback vs waiting for local leaders to input; addresses complaint logging transparency (Ball: only 14 complaints in 7 months)
Aaron Simpson.context: Aaron identified a data transparency problem: Ball portfolio showed only 14 complaints in 7 months, which didn't match client perception. Root cause: area managers weren't logging all feedback. Solution: Aaron now conducts bi-weekly scorecard reviews directly with Regional Facility Managers (RFMs), not just area managers, capturing feedback in real-time instead of waiting for local leaders to input it. Valarie Barnett's reaction: 'Almost like a reset... different level of transparency... really helpful for CBRE.' This ensures the data in 4insite actually reflects reality, which is critical for client trust. Highly replicable for any AD with data accuracy challenges.
Aaron Simpson.impact: Val: 'Almost like a reset... different level of transparency... really helpful for CBRE'
Aaron Simpson.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett noted as helpful for CBRE partnership

Aaron Simpson.title: Headcount-to-Outcomes Pivot Strategy
Aaron Simpson.description: Use model sites (Lebanon TN, Cleveland TN, Leipzig OH) to show outcomes achieved without headcount increases; embed local supervisors with Mars sanitation leads (not just CBRE as middleman); reframe from 'position-driven' to 'outcome-driven'
Aaron Simpson.context: At Mars, the client was fixated on headcount ('You need X people per shift'). Aaron strategically pivoted to outcomes by showcasing model sites (Lebanon TN, Cleveland TN, Leipzig OH) that achieve excellent results without headcount increases. He embedded local SBM supervisors directly with Mars sanitation leads (not just relying on CBRE as middleman) to align on outcomes, not positions. This reframes success from 'position-driven' (how many people) to 'outcome-driven' (are the spaces clean?). Valarie Barnett acknowledged this strategic reframing as critical for reducing margin pressure while maintaining client satisfaction. Highly replicable for any account with headcount-focused clients.
Aaron Simpson.impact: Changes client success metrics; reduces margin pressure

Brian Davis.title: Cross-Portfolio Expert Leverage Model
Brian Davis.description: Leverage dedicated resources across Merck portfolio (CBRE, Sodexo, Direct); pull in experts from one account to support another (e.g., Justin from CBRE as pest control expert for Direct sites)
Brian Davis.context: Brian manages Merck across three IFM partners (CBRE, Sodexo, Direct) with dedicated SBM resources on each. Rather than siloing expertise, he created a cross-portfolio leverage model where specialists can be pulled from one account to support another. For example, Justin from the CBRE account serves as the pest control expert for Direct sites. The scale of the portfolio supports complex problem-solving without additional client cost - 'We've got the whole team' available. Marvin Owens noted this strategic advantage as a best practice for large multi-partner accounts where SBM can provide continuity and expertise that IFMs can't match individually.
Brian Davis.impact: Scale of account supports problem-solving without additional cost; 'We've got the whole team'
Brian Davis.leadership_endorsement: Marvin Owens noted strategic advantage of portfolio structure

Brian Davis.title: Leading Merck IFM Workplace Experience Community of Practice
Brian Davis.description: Took over workplace experience community of practice; presented final survey results to Merck leadership; collaborated with CBRE and Sodexo on contractual protections (e.g., scoring methodology)
Brian Davis.context: Marvin Owens handed off the Merck Workplace Experience Community of Practice leadership to Brian, positioning SBM (not CBRE or Sodexo) as the thought leader. Brian presented final survey results directly to Merck executive leadership and collaborated with other IFMs on contractual protections like scoring methodology. This forced collaboration across IFMs (where SBM leads, not follows) and increased executive-level visibility for SBM. The strategic value: when Merck thinks 'workplace experience,' they think SBM first, not the larger IFM partners. This is partnership positioning at its best.
Brian Davis.impact: Positioned SBM as IFM thought leader; forced collaboration across IFMs; increased visibility to executive leadership
Brian Davis.leadership_endorsement: Marvin Owens handed off to Brian; executive-level visibility

Brian Davis.title: MYO (Multi-Year Optimization) Custodial SLA Leadership
Brian Davis.description: Leading custodial SLA optimization for Merck's $3B savings initiative (patent cliff); using education sector 4-level service model; Merck already positioning SBM to lead
Brian Davis.context: Merck is facing a patent cliff requiring $3B in savings across all services. For the Multi-Year Optimization (MYO) custodial SLA redesign, Merck leadership (Michael Gardner, Pierre Leo) is already positioning SBM to lead - not CBRE, not Sodexo. Brian is applying an education sector 4-level service model to create tiered custodial standards. The strategic win: 'If we're looking at optimizing custodial, it's SBM.' This positions SBM as the optimization thought leader across all IFMs in a $3B initiative, creating massive visibility and influence on future scope decisions. Leadership sees this as enterprise-level strategic positioning.
Brian Davis.impact: Positions SBM as optimization leader across all IFMs; 'If we're looking at optimizing custodial, it's SBM'
Brian Davis.leadership_endorsement: Michael Gardner, Pierre Leo positioning SBM to lead

Justin Homa.title: Lab Cleaning Optimization Through Time Studies
Justin Homa.description: Conducted detailed time study including cleaning times AND travel times across 60 buildings covering 154 labs; reduced lab cleaning frequency from weekly to bi-weekly
Justin Homa.context: Justin conducted a comprehensive time study across 60 buildings covering 154 labs at Merck, measuring not just cleaning times but also travel times between buildings. The data supported reducing lab cleaning frequency from weekly to bi-weekly without compromising quality. This delivered $190K/year in savings (2.8% of total contract) plus avoided $44K in new construction labor costs. CBRE highlighted this as their 'huge success story for savings for 2025.' The methodology is highly replicable - most vendors guess at cleaning frequencies, but Justin used data to prove what's actually needed. Valarie Barnett praised this as the kind of strategic cost reduction that strengthens rather than weakens partnerships.
Justin Homa.impact: $190k/year savings (2.8%) + avoided $44k in new construction labor costs; CBRE's 'huge success story for savings for 2025'
Justin Homa.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett praised; CBRE leadership highlighted as success story

Justin Homa.title: Colo Dispenser Program for Waste Reduction
Justin Homa.description: Installed Colo dispensers at non-production sites; set progressive goals (13% → 10% → 8% → 5%); monthly meetings with Colo team to review dashboard data
Justin Homa.context: Justin installed Colo dispensers at Merck non-production sites and set aggressive progressive waste reduction goals: 13% → 10% → 8% → 5%. Through monthly meetings with the Colo team reviewing dashboard data, he reduced consumable waste from 33% to under 5% - a massive sustainability win. CBRE funded the $100K+ equipment investment. Valarie Barnett told Justin: 'Extra credit in 2026 if you put together a white paper on this' - comparing it to John Mann's famous white paper success. This is a replicable model for any account with sustainability goals and demonstrates how data-driven programs create client investment rather than cost reduction.
Justin Homa.impact: Reduced consumable waste from 33% to under 5%; CBRE funded $100k+ equipment investment
Justin Homa.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett: 'Extra credit in 2026 if you put together a white paper on this'; Praised like John Mann's white paper success

Justin Homa.title: Always Audit-Ready Culture
Justin Homa.description: Zero observations/findings across ALL SBM managed services (janitorial, pest control, uniforms, waste) in all internal and external agency audits; continuous audit readiness vs. cramming
Justin Homa.context: In pharmaceutical/GMP environments, most vendors 'prepare for audits' with last-minute scrambles. Justin created an 'always audit-ready' culture at Merck where sites are inspected weekly as if an audit is tomorrow. Result: Zero observations/findings across ALL SBM-managed services (janitorial, pest control, uniforms, waste) in both 2024 AND 2025 across all internal and external agency audits. Merck and CBRE effusively praised this partnership standard. This sets the industry benchmark for pharmaceutical compliance and is scalable to all GMP/regulated environments. It also reduces liability risk and builds unshakeable client confidence in SBM's operational discipline.
Justin Homa.impact: Zero findings in 2024 AND 2025; 'A lot of praise from Merck and CBRE as a partner'
Justin Homa.leadership_endorsement: Merck and CBRE partnership praise; sets industry standard

Justin Dallavis.title: Angel's Huntsville Turnaround (Leadership Volunteerism)
Justin Dallavis.description: Angel (Chicago SM) volunteered to move to Huntsville for turnaround; 'knew exactly what he was walking into'; failing CSATs/audits to perfect CSAT scores; identified successor (Robert Brimmer, 30yr Chicago lead) before leaving
Justin Dallavis.context: When Huntsville was failing (poor CSATs, failed audits), Angel - the site manager from Chicago - volunteered to move to Alabama for a turnaround assignment. He 'knew exactly what he was walking into' but went anyway. Result: complete transformation from failing to perfect CSAT scores. Before leaving Huntsville, Angel proactively identified and trained his Chicago successor Robert Brimmer (a 30-year veteran Chicago lead), documented all processes, and conducted shadow training over 60 days. JLL's feedback: 'They no longer have any janitorial concerns.' Leadership praised Angel's commitment and succession planning discipline. This enables strategic talent deployment while reducing knowledge loss risk.
Justin Dallavis.impact: 'Complete transformation'; JLL: 'They no longer have any janitorial concerns'
Justin Dallavis.leadership_endorsement: Client effusive about transformation; leadership praised Angel's commitment

Justin Dallavis.title: Equipment Investment for Time Efficiency
Justin Dallavis.description: Kaivax (all-in-one restroom cleaner: power washer, chemical spray, toilet brush, shop vac, floor scrub in one); Viper riding scrubbers; Tenant ride-on vacuums; Whittaker carpet spotters (crystallization, no extraction/blowers needed)
Justin Dallavis.context: Justin invested strategically in equipment that cuts cleaning times in half: Kaivax all-in-one restroom cleaners, Viper riding scrubbers, Tenant ride-on vacuums, and Whittaker carpet spotters (crystallization method, no extraction/blowers needed). This created capacity for additional routes at no extra labor cost - like adding an OKC daytime recycle tech for free. Window cleaning in-house now saves Boeing ~$6K per clean. Extended carpet life reduces replacement costs. James Peate highlighted this when asked to quantify value. The key: invest in tools that create time, then redeploy that time to add value rather than cutting costs. Highly replicable across all accounts.
Justin Dallavis.impact: Cut cleaning times in half; extended carpet life; created capacity for additional routes (e.g., OKC daytime recycle tech at no cost); ~$6K savings per window clean
Justin Dallavis.leadership_endorsement: James Peate noted when asked to quantify value

Justin Dallavis.title: ForSight Compliance Tracking System
Justin Dallavis.description: Implemented compliance tracking system and weekly coaching sessions with teams to drive ForSight adoption; significantly improved usage and data quality
Justin Dallavis.context: Justin implemented a disciplined ForSight compliance tracking system with weekly coaching sessions for site teams to drive adoption and data quality. Result: 1,875 audits completed in 2025 with a 4.5 average score, 99% on-time response, 99% on-time closure, 100% satisfaction, and 100% invoice accuracy. Valarie Barnett said 'I'm comfortable with your ForSight skills' - high praise indicating Justin can now train others. James Peate praised the diligence. This systematic approach to technology adoption (training + accountability + coaching) is replicable across all ADs struggling with ForSight usage. The key: make it a discipline, not just a tool.
Justin Dallavis.impact: 1875 audits completed in 2025; 4.5 average score; 99% on-time response, 99% on-time closure, 100% satisfaction, 100% invoice accuracy
Justin Dallavis.leadership_endorsement: Valarie Barnett: 'I'm comfortable with your ForSight skills'; James Peate praised diligence

Dave Pergola.title: Site Consolidation Without Disruption
Dave Pergola.description: Managed consolidation of Kenilworth and Madison locations into Rahway HQ, doubling headcount from 3,000 to 6,500 without disrupting business continuity
Dave Pergola.context: Merck consolidated operations to save on facility costs and upgrade infrastructure. Dave coordinated entire project with zero union grievances, no work stoppages, no escalations. Required extensive transitional calls with Sodexo and Merck to ensure effective communication and stakeholder alignment throughout.
Dave Pergola.impact: Seamless transition with no operational disruptions; demonstrated effectiveness in managing complex change and stakeholder engagement

Dave Pergola.title: Strategic Value-Add Conversion ($69K/month ATB → Base Revenue)
Dave Pergola.description: Delivered cost-neutral cleaning services for RY3034 executive spaces (Conference Center, ADB Office Center, Wellness Center) worth $69K/month, then negotiated incorporation into base scope
Dave Pergola.context: Instead of charging ATB immediately, Dave provided services 'in good faith' to demonstrate partnership and help Merck find efficiencies. Strategic play: give value now, convert to permanent base revenue growth later. With new work releases, all recurring ATB (including this $69K/month) will be incorporated into base scope.
Dave Pergola.impact: $69K/month value-add converted into base revenue growth; demonstrated flexibility and client-first partnership
Dave Pergola.leadership_endorsement: Valarie: 'Congratulations on that. So now you were doing something for free as a value add that you then flipped into...'

Dave Pergola.title: Direct Contractor Revenue Protection ($475K ATB)
Dave Pergola.description: Specialized cleaning services for Merck's direct construction/decommissioning projects and contractor trailers - $475K ATB revenue protected from IFM partner claiming management fees
Dave Pergola.context: Sodexo attempted to claim management fees on this revenue, arguing they manage SBM. Dave/team pushed back: 'We're under contract with you for Merck AND we're under a direct contract with this construction company - we should not pay you on top of getting paid for work outside our contract.' Successfully protected revenue stream.
Dave Pergola.impact: $475K annual revenue retained; positioned for growth as new buildings come online
Dave Pergola.leadership_endorsement: Marvin: 'This is that revenue that Sodexo was trying to get their hands on that we pushed back on'

Dave Pergola.title: Centralized Trashing Model Campus-Wide
Dave Pergola.description: 50+ centralized trash stations installed campus-wide (ABW buildings Phase 1, expanding to full campus Phase 2)
Dave Pergola.context: Eliminated office-by-office trash collection, freeing up labor for critical tasks. Result: 25% increase in servicing efficiency, 2% reduction in recycling contamination, cleanliness ratings improved 3.5 → 3.8 out of 5. Cost savings from reduced productivity time and liner consumption.
Dave Pergola.impact: Operational efficiency increased 25%; employee satisfaction improved; cost savings from labor/consumables
Dave Pergola.leadership_endorsement: Valarie: 'I think this is probably exemplary. Best practice could be shared throughout SBM.'

Dave Pergola.title: ABW Portering Optimization ($404K Savings)
Dave Pergola.description: Optimized activity-based workstation porter services (5 FTEs reduced), delivering $404K cost savings while maintaining quality standards
Dave Pergola.context: Reduced service hours without sacrificing user experience. Stable complaint rates, SLA adherence maintained. Effective stakeholder communication and performance metric monitoring were crucial to validate savings and maintain service quality.
Dave Pergola.impact: $404K annual savings; demonstrated ability to reduce costs without quality degradation
